After that, I started my orthopedic residency, which is specific to the subspecialty of orthopedic surgery, and that was a four-year program.  I completed that as chief resident in 1986.  At that point, I started my practice.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you tell us about your professional experience.

text: As far as what I do on a daily basis, I operated on individuals for over 30 years, provided conservative care for injuries and some disease states that have to do with joints, particularly where they wear out and you have to address that.  I took call in the emergency room for that amount of time and also treated individuals in the office setting. In the early 1990s, I started doing more formalized pain management, particularly injecting more areas of the body in the spinal column and joints, muscles, tendons, ligaments and nerves and doing that kind of work along with the individuals who have not only metabolic diseases again but injuries, as well.

text: This seems like a silly question, but I have to ask. Are you licensed to practice medicine in the state of Pennsylvania?

The process to get there entailed, in the first certificate, three years of taking tests and the last year actually being observed doing surgery in the operating room by two board certified individuals.  I reviewed records in the hospital and office setting.  That was all compiled, and I received my first certificate in 1989. The process after that is just to take written tests, and I did that successfully three times to the current time.  I hold a certificate that still designates me as an orthopedic surgeon. I stopped doing surgery in 2013.  I still see individuals because of the pain management side of treatment who have injuries, so it goes hand in hand, so to speak. Basically, for pain management, I do interventional techniques, injecting individuals and also treating and designing programs for people who require therapy and also modalities, such as medications, as well.

Also, on the scenes, we have to determine whether there is a crime along with the detectives who are out on the scene when there is a gunshot wound and those kinds of findings. All of that comes under forensics, and we rely on forensic pathologists to do the ultimate evaluation of the individual in their lab. text: - - - DIRECT EXAMINATION
Dr. Yarus, we're here to take your testimony on behalf of Fr. Mularczyk related to his injuries and treatment following the accident that occurred on April 19, 2018, correct?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes, that's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: I did, yes.

speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes, I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: After your examination and review of the records, you produced reports that contained your opinions concerning this matter?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you please look at the documents that have been marked as Yarus-2 and -3 respectively.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are those your reports?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: They are, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: During the course of your testimony today, I'm going to ask you to refer to your reports as needed; is that fair?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes, I will do that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In a moment, I'm going to ask you to walk the jury through your physical examination and evaluation of Fr. Mularczyk and his records step by step. But before I do that, can you explain to the jury what injuries, if any, Fr. Mularczyk sustained as a result of the April 19, 2018 accident?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Off the record.
speaker: MR. RONG

text: The time is 3:52.  Off the video record.
speaker: THE VIDEOGRAPHER

text: (Whereupon, a discussion was held off the videotaped record.)

I'm laying an objection on the record.  First, the general comment I'd like to make is this objection is being made because counsel made a similar objection at the time of Dr. Fras' deposition, his trial deposition. I believe it to be a frivolous objection.  However, I wanted to reserve my right to argue it in this context, if necessary. The objection being that, given that the doctor has conceded that he is not an accident reconstructionist, that he cannot render a conclusion as to what injuries were sustained during this accident because that would require his ability to understand how the body would operate or change or be affected in a fall or whatever Mr. Mularczyk is claiming happened as a mechanism in his accident. That is an objection I'm only placing on the record to reserve the right to argue it.  However, I believe that the objection that was made at Dr. Fras' deposition was a frivolous objection.
speaker: MR. RONG

text: Before we got started today, counsel gave me the professional courtesy of a heads-up, which was greatly appreciated, but I believe Dr. Yarus is more than qualified to discuss what injuries were sustained as a result of Fr. Mularczyk's accident on April 19, 2018. He's already gone through his qualifications, which are more than adequate.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: 3:55. Back on the record.
speaker: THE VIDEOGRAPHER

text: Fr. Mularczyk injured two areas of the body.  One is the low back.  We call that the lumbar spine. The other is the right shoulder. I broke down the types of injuries that were sustained into soft tissue injuries.  Then we'll talk about the discs in relation to the nerves that come out and supply motor and sensory functions. For the low back, he had a strain and sprain; a term I use, lumbar myositis, which is a covering of the muscles, which was inflamed.  I actually used an osteopathic term, that is somatic dysfunction.  It just means that, because the muscles, tendons, and ligaments are injured, the motion and function of the lumbar spine becomes altered. I also used a term called enthesopathy.  The enthesis -- and I'll show this on a model in a couple seconds here -- is the area of bone in the spine where these ligaments and tendons attach so that we can get motion and stability of the spine. Going to the discs, at L3-4 and L4-5 -- we designate the levels by two vertebrae and the disc is in the middle -- those had protrusions.  At 4-5, there was sequestration of the disc fragment that was going caudally to the left of the midline with encroachment. Breaking down all those terms, basically the disc came out of its containment area.  If we think about a jelly doughnut, putting pressure on the doughnut and the jelly coming out, this jelly actually goes away from the doughnut and it starts to go toward the top part of the vertebral body, which is called -- I'm sorry, caudad is lower; it goes down below.  Cephalad would be the upper.  Caudad is low, my apologies. Anyway, the disc went down away from the level where it would usually be situated.  At L5-S1, there was also a protrusion, as well.  This was going to the left. All these discs from 3-4, 5-S1, which stands for sacrum, that's the next bone below the last vertebrae in the spinal column, they were going left. The radiculopathy on the left comes from pressure on the nerve from the discs.  This was identified clinically at L4-5 and L5-S1 by my examination. In regard to the right shoulder, there was a contusion.  Then there was an MRI that was done, and it showed one of the four tendons of the rotator cuff to be torn. That's called the supraspinatus. Lastly, I said that Fr. Mularczyk had chronic pain secondary to the incident of April 19, 2018 and also a decrease in the activities in which he participated secondary to that incident, as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have an opinion within a reasonable degree of medical certainty as to whether any of these injuries are serious?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Which ones?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: I believe the disc injuries as well as the tear in the rotator cuff, supraspinatus tendon, to be the most serious.  The soft tissue injuries are certainly permanent in nature.  They're higher grade, but I will classify those below those injuries that are disc oriented and the shoulder injury involving the actual structure that's part of the cuff.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have an opinion within a reasonable degree of medical certainty whether any of these injuries that you just discussed pertaining to the accident that brings us here today are permanent?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Which ones?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Well, if we talk about soft tissue injuries, a lot of times sprains and strains and muscle, tendon, and ligament injuries will go away if they're low grade.  So we grade them up to a Roman numeral 4.  These are fours.  So what happens in the collagen fibers of the muscle particularly is it scars.  That's permanent.  It's not going to go away. In regard to the discs, the discs are out of their containment fibers.  They're pressing on the nerve, so that creates the radicular pain, the reproduction of that symptom and finding. Irrespective of what you do to correct that, even up to and including surgery, the effects of surgery are still there.  Some of the known effects of surgery, such as scarring particularly, will still be there, so it's permanent, as well. You may be able to help the person and improve their situation by doing it, but the effects are still there.  So I will classify that as permanent, as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let's talk about some of the terms that you used in discussing the injuries that Fr. Mularczyk received as a result of this subsequent. Let's start with the lumbar spine.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: In order to understand what I was talking about, this is a representation of the lumbar spine.  It contains four vertebral bodies.  There is actually five in total, but the concept is that each vertebral body has a disc in between.  We'll number them 4, 5, et cetera. What happens with the disc is that it's surrounded by containment fibers.  I mentioned that.  They're called annular fibers.  They have nerves in them, and they will send the signals that there is pain. When the disc comes out, this is what it looks like, and the nerves are right behind that supply motor and sensory functions to the extremities.  If disc is coming out at one level or more than one level, it will have an affect of the extremities at various levels, particularly for the sensory component of the nerve that supplies that function.  That's the front part of the person. As we keep turning, we see holes where these nerves come out.  At each level on the right and left, the main nerves -- I'll call them main nerves because there's other nerves we're going to talk about -- they come out and supply that sensory and motor function. As we keep turning, we're now at the back of the person.  This is the bone you can feel at the center of your back and all the way up to your neck.  This is true of the whole spinal column. There are motion segments here.  I'm putting the needle in the left side.  This will be the right side for that level.  These are called facets.  They are actually joints. This is where motion occurs. I mentioned the enthesis or enthesopathy, where I'm putting the needles where the ligaments attach, another smaller structure that help move the spine at these areas. One other thing to mention because we're going to talk about treatment, there are small nerves, where I'm putting the needle, situated under the facets.  These are called medial branch nerves.  They're the nerves that send the pain signal to the brain when there is injury at these levels.  We can knock out those nerves by burning them.  The reason we can do that -- not the main nerves, but these little nerves -- is because they will regenerate or come back. We can give the person pain relief by doing that particular procedure, which is called a rhizotomy or ablation.  That's the anatomy of the low back.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you explain to us -- you used the word protrusion, I believe?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is a protrusion?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: There are three faces of disc that can come out of the containment fibers.  The first is a bulge.  Sometimes bulging is normal because the disc is designed to absorb forces, but when it comes out, that's the first type.  I have a model for that one, too. What it looks like is basically just coming out a little bit.  The next phase would be a protrusion, which is what we're talking about here for Fr. Mularczyk, and then a herniation, which is totally a disc that's out. Fr. Mularczyk has a disc that actually came out and then went downward as far as where it ended up being situated.  Once that disc comes out, the nerve is right there, and when it sits up on a nerve or compresses it, that's when you get radicular symptoms. When we talk about radiculopathy, it's coming from this mechanical phenomena of the disc itself sitting up on the nerve, as I like to say.  The correct term is compression of the nerve.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is a disc protrusion a normal condition?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: It is not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is a protrusion a painful condition?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: It definitely is, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You just used the term radiculopathy?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you please explain exactly what radiculopathy is.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Radiculopathy is a person complaining of radiating symptoms in an extremity; in this case, the lower extremities.  That comes from the disc sitting up on the nerve.  Once the nerve is compressed, it doesn't fire correctly. When I examined Fr. Mularczyk, he had reproduction of radiating symptoms, so I gave clinical diagnosis.  We don't have any testing to show that.  There is electrical evaluation that can be done.  But clinically, you can also tell radiculopathy is there by reproducing those symptom.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is radiculopathy a normal condition?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: It is not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is it a painful condition?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: It definitely is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you explain to us the shoulder injury that Fr. Mularczyk received as a result of the accident?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yeah, I can.  This is a representation of a right shoulder.  We're talking about the right for Fr. Mularczyk.  What I'm showing here is the bone that we call the humerus. This is the square bone you can feel on the outside of your shoulder.  This comes off of the wing bone, that's the scapula. That particular part of it that we can feel here is the acromion.  The acromion is acutely related to the collar bone or the clavicle.  There are ligaments that span those two bones to stabilize them, all these three ligaments here. This is the first tendon of the rotator cuff that attaches into the outside of the humerus bone.  That's called the supraspinatus.  There is three others in the whole cuff.  It spells the words, sits, SITS. This is the one that Fr. Mularczyk had a tear in from the incident, and this is the one that's most typically torn.  It sits right underneath that square bone.  As the shoulder moves upward, when there is a tear, it's going to cause pain because it's going to get crimped between the head of the bone of the humerus and the undersurface of the acromion.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How do the back injuries that Fr. Mularczyk suffered as a result of the accident affect his day-to-day activities?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: They're going to diminish the activities.  That was the last part of my conclusions; that he had a diminution or decrease in his ability to function, not only the low back, but from the shoulder itself. When you're doing activities when you have these injuries, it's going to slow you down.  It's going to cause pain, and you're not going to be able to function the way you normally do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have an opinion as to the permanency?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is that?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: These have permanency to them.  That word means that it affects the individual's ability to function in their lifestyle, whatever it may be.  When it hinders or diminishes, we call that permanency.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How about the shoulder, how do the injuries he received as a result of the accident to his shoulder affect his day-to-day?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Well, the ability to reach, maneuver in the motions of the shoulder, which are forward, backward, internal/external rotation, circumduction, like you're going to throw a ball, reaching back, those types of things, putting your clothing on, a coat or shirt. All of these things that we do that a lot of us take for granted, I do too, become difficult because those motions create pain for the reason I showed on the model.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have an opinion as to the permanency of that condition?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is it?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: This is a term again that applies to Fr. Mularczyk not being able to function normally using the shoulder girdle, that particular area that we showed.  It is a difficult issue with activities, and that becomes a permanent issue.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'd like to get into your examination and history of Fr. Mularczyk.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Off the record.
speaker: MR. RONG

text: The time is 4:09.  Off the video record.
speaker: THE VIDEOGRAPHER

text: (Whereupon, a discussion was held off the videotaped record.)

This is in the same vein as the prior objection that was made. There was an objection made by plaintiff's counsel during Dr. Fras' deposition regarding anything that was said by the plaintiff to Dr. Fras regarding history related to this accident and his treatment. I believe that to be a frivolous objection.  However, similar to the prior objection, I'm just reserving the right to argue that objection in this context in Dr. Yarus' deposition if this is something we agree to proceed at the time of trial.
speaker: MR. RONG

text: To that, Dr. Yarus testified during his qualifications that taking a history is part of what he does as part of his normal everyday practice in treating and evaluating patients.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: The time is 4:11.  Back on the video record.
speaker: THE VIDEOGRAPHER

text: Dr. Yarus, when you examined Fr. Mularczyk, did you ask about the accident of April 19, 2018?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: I did, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did he tell you?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: His complaints were right shoulder pain and low back pain.  Then he told me that he drove over a pothole and the tire exploded.  He had to change the tire, and when he was doing so, the tire fell on top of him.  He described himself as being slammed and pinned by the tire. We then discussed the treatment that he had at Spinal Care and Progress Physical Therapy, the injections that Dr. Levinstein provided. When he presented, he was using a cane.  He did tell me that the injections helped somewhat.  He had had pain in the shoulder that was still present.  Then I asked him particularly how he was feeling, and he told me that his pain level was 6 out of 10 on what we call the analog scale.  That includes the low back and the right shoulder. The pain was at its worst then.  When resting or not performing activities, 1 to 2 out of 10.  He had radiating pain to both lower extremities.  That's the radicular component we were talking about.  And he had headache and fatigue. He had actually undergone surgery for the right shoulder, and he said that had helped him, as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you saw him, he was still having pain from the accident?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: He still was, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you ask Fr. Mularczyk about his medical history prior to this accident?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: I did, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What did he tell you?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Well, as far as medication, he was taking ibuprofen 600 milligrams, surgical history included the right shoulder.  Then I asked him about preexisting conditions.  This is a section in the history taking where we want to find out if there is any prior injuries or issues with the same areas. He did have the two prior low back issues; one in 2010 without injury.  2012 he had spinal stenosis, which is a term that just means arthritis, and that was causing difficulty for him, and he had surgery for that, which improved him. He said he had minimal residuals up to and including the incident of April 19, 2019. That means that he wasn't completely recovered, but he didn't have the same kind of symptoms that he experienced after this incident occurred.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You examined Fr. Mularczyk?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: I did, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you walk the jury through your examination.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes.  I did a complete full exam, but I'll stick to the areas of chief complaint. He was 6-foot-2-inches tall, 240 pounds.  From the low back, he had a loss of lordosis.  This is a manifestation of what happens when muscles, tendons, and ligaments and those soft tissues are injured.  The natural curve that we see in the low back becomes flattened.  I observed that. In touching the muscles, he had hypertonicity from L3-4 to L5-S1.  Left greater than right.  I did what's called a sitting root and straight leg raising sign. There is various degrees of raising in terms of looking at the number of degrees. His left showed 15 and 15.  Right was positive as well at 20 and 25 degrees.  That just means, when I lifted, he had reproduction of his root signs.  That's where I got the radiculopathy diagnosis from. His motion of the spine was 40 percent of normal, and that includes going forward, backward, side to side, and rotating.  There were no cord signs.  We call those long-tract signs.  Those were not evident, so his spinal cord was fine.  The vasculature in his extremities was okay, so we didn't have any issues there. The next thing I did is reflex testing.  This is the most important thing as far as examination because when there is abnormality, as there was here, it reflects back up to the spine.  By that I mean those levels that I showed, those nerves that come out, those are the ones that will show me or anybody doing this test whether or not there is a particular problem at a particular level. We do the kneecap reflexes, and those were okay, so that covers L3-4.  Then we did the extensor hallucis.  There is no tap reflex for L4-5, so we ask the person to lift the great toe.  There was a left deficit 4 out of 5.  The right was okay at 5 out of 5. The last one we do is the Achilles reflex.  That reflects to L5-S1.  The right was 2 out of 3, that's abnormal.  The left was 1 out of 3. Next, I test that sensory component of the radiculopathy by doing pinpricking down along the back all the way down the extremity.  There are bands that will correspond to the level.  When there is a deficit or the person tells me they can't feel it as well as they did upper or lower or side to side, comparing right or left, it's abnormal.  For Fr. Mularczyk, it was abnormal on the left at L4-5; abnormal at L5-S1 for both the right and left. Next, I did the extremity examination. No edema.  No other abnormalities or painful masses.  Neck area was okay.  He had had surgery for the shoulder, so I would say that the shoulder was improved after that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That was a lot of information.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What were your findings based on your physical examination?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: For the low back particularly, because that was the focus here, there is abnormalities on a lot of levels.  When we look at the soft tissue.  That was abnormal. That corresponds to my diagnosis for that area in the low back. Then the motion was deficient, so that comes along again with the soft tissue injury.  Looking at the reflexes, those are abnormal.  I said they're the most important because when you have protrusions, going back to that explanation and discussion, those protrusions are discs sitting up on the nerves.  The nerves become affected, and then we have abnormal reflexes as a result of that. That's what I was talking about when I gave those numbers 1 out of 3, 2 out of 3. And looking at and extensor hallucis, the great toe lift, on a 5 scale that was 4 out of 5 on the left.  That's why that came about.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: These are all permanent impairments?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: They are, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

I'm going to make that same objection in this deposition. Again, I believe it to be a frivolous objection.  I believe that, based upon both experts having testified that they regularly use radiology exams in the course of their treatment, that they are both permitted to testify to this. However, if plaintiff's counsel, at the time of trial, is going to insist on this objection regarding Dr. Fras' ability to testify to anything that he reviewed in these reports or films, I'm similarly reserving the right to make this objection in the context of Dr. Yarus' deposition.

text: I had actual hard copy studies on a disc that included the right shoulder and low back, the lumbar spine.  I was able to visualize the study. I'll tell you that what the radiologist read was pretty accurate as far as my interpretation on my own.  I agreed pretty much with what was seen as abnormal, particularly on both of those studies. For the right shoulder, an actual tear in the supraspinatus tendon, which was partial thickness.  No evidence of inflammation in the bursal sacs that are situated between the bones.  The glenoid labrum, which is a lip that surrounds the socket where the head rides, that was okay. The biceps tendon was okay.  Some arthritic changes in the AC joint.  We see that all the time.  That wasn't an issue for Fr. Mularczyk.  It was just an incidental finding. For the low back, just to make it simple, the three discs that were protruding that I saw and one other one that the radiologist indicated; L2-3 showed a protrusion on the left.  I don't think that's an issue clinically.  I'll acknowledge that it's there, but I don't think it's causing the symptomatology that the other three are. I agreed there, and basically those discs are going to the left. I had the records of Spinal Care, Progress Physical Therapy, Dr. Levinstein's practice is PA Pain Practice, so I had his records for the injections, particularly Penn Medicine medical records, and then the billing and invoicing on an open item ledger and the actual Pennsylvania Pain Specialist invoicing that was provided.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Describe what, if anything, you learned of significance in reviewing these records.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: I think the records are clear in that Fr. Mularczyk had these injuries born out of this incident of April 19, 2018.  Those injuries were addressed with conservative care, interventional technique by Dr. Levinstein on two occasions. He did epidural injections, I believe, August 6th and 20th of 2018, then just confirmation looking through the studies that there were injuries in those areas that we described.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you briefly explain to the jury what an MRI is.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: MRI stands for magnetic resonance imaging.  It's a sophisticated piece of equipment that has a large magnet.  It rotates at super rapid speed.  When that happens, the plus and minus that you see on the magnet becomes blurred essentially, and it reorganizes protons in the body.  A computer is hooked up to the magnet that will interpret whatever anatomy you're visualizing, and it will put it out in two forms, T1 and T2. We're able to see bone windows, and we're able to see the soft tissue structures; in this case, discs in reference to nerves. In the shoulder, we're able to see the anatomy that is made up of the cuff, the labrum and the bone components as well and anything that's wrong or not right, such as loose bodies or tumors, things of that nature.  We can discern that. Fr. Mularczyk does not have any tumors, just to be clear.  It's just as a way of describing what this sophisticated test can do as far as giving us the visualization of the anatomy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm going to show you what we've had marked as Yarus-4 for identification. Doctor, do you recognize that document?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: I do, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: I gave him a guarded prognosis.  The reason for that terminology is that there is still items that will be affected for Fr. Mularczyk to consider as far as treatment.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you briefly explain what a prognosis is.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Prognosis is a term that will drive future indications for treatment for an individual.  It takes a lot into consideration; all about the individual including financial issues, what they're capable of doing and what responses from a statistical standpoint and statistical analysis standpoint we know will be effective from just those specific injuries.  There is a litany of information at our disposal that leads us to be able to do that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You briefly touched on why you thought he had a guarded prognosis.  Could you flesh that out for us a little bit more.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: We're still going to make recommendations in the guarded phase as opposed to variable, poor, good even. In this phase, we know that making recommendations for treatment is going to be effective statistically for the individual. That's all we're looking at when we see this particular term used.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Based on your diagnosis, prognosis, examination of Fr. Mularczyk and review of the records, do you have an opinion as to whether or not Fr. Mularczyk will require future treatment for the injuries suffered as a result of the accident that brings us here today?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is that opinion?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: That he will need future treatment.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What recommendations did you make about his future medical treatment?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: I talked about interventional care for the low back, and that includes the burning of the small nerves that knocks out the pain. Certainly, there are epidurals similar to what Dr. Levinstein did.  You can repeat those in a series of three at six-month intervals.  Lastly, operating on those areas where the discs are out, to take out the disc and relieve the nerve of its compression. For the shoulder, I talked about arthroscopy, which is a procedure that he had done.  Because these areas scar as a way of healing, you can't get back what was originally there.  It's not like the skin. If you cut skin, skin will repair itself, maybe with some help of suturing perhaps. But if you suture or you address the tear in the cuff, the only way the body has to heal it is by scar.  That's why I said it's a permanent injury.  You still have to go back in and clean it up, which will give the person better range of motion. I talked about therapy after any of these procedures are done.  That's for a short period of time.  I talked about various types of medications that can be used, including pain medication, anti-inflammatories.  There are more sophisticated medications that address the nerves.  Those are neurotransmitter modulators.  We can actually use anti-epileptics, which are effective.  And for the soft tissue injuries, we use creams that can be applied, as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Dr. Yarus, why did you make these recommendations regarding future treatment for Fr. Mularczyk?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: - - - REDIRECT EXAMINATION
I just have a couple follow-ups. Dr. Yarus, you were asked how much you charge for the exams?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You do this as an expert, yes?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: About 10 to 15 percent of my total time spent as a physician is in this kind of arena, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know any experts who do this for free?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: I think some of us, if it calls for it, will give a free deposition here and there, but I like to get paid for my time. Most of the time I do get paid for my time doing these types of depositions or evaluations.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It's fair to say that you expect to be paid for your work?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Sure, absolutely I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Counsel asked you about how much you've been paid between 2018 and 2019 for your expert services from the Simon law firm. Do you recall that?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: I think he went from 2014 up to the present perhaps, but, yes, I remember the question.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm sorry, did I miss 2014 to the present?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: I believe that was the timeframe, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Over five years, I believe you said approximately $2 million?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let's put this in perspective. How many offices do you have, Dr. Yarus?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Right now I have three offices.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The money that you bring in for litigation -- and not just from the Simon law firm but from the litigation work that you do across the board -- - where does that go?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Well, it goes to the practice.  It doesn't go in my pocket.  If you know anything about businesses, even the medical business and I'll call it that, it's 65 percent overhead.  So we have to pay for those offices, the lighting, electricity, the people that I employ and I'm part of that corporation as the sole physician, but all of these expenses go into keeping this going. It's pretty hefty as far as percentages.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many employees do you have?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: In this office, I have three.  I have two others in Pittsburgh.  I have probably seven to eight at any given time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You were asked about whether or not Fr. Mularczyk missed any time from work. How would you characterize his physical requirements?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Well, he's a preacher.  As a pastor, unless he's doing Habitat For Humanity and those kinds of things, physically I don't think it's a demanding job.  It's a tentorial job, meaning he uses his brain and his knowledge to do what he does.  I would say it's a minimally stressful job as far as activity.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You were asked about, I think, what we've had marked as Yarus-4, that was Dr. Rosin?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who was treating Fr. Mularczyk?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Pertaining to the report, Dr. Rosin said that Fr. Mularczyk received injuries sustained in a motor vehicle accident, which occurred on April 19, 2018, correct?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I want to talk a little bit about the MRI, specifically of the shoulder. You were asked about whether or not there was any edema or bleeding?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, as it pertains to the shoulder, the labrum was torn; is that correct -- or there was a shoulder tear?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Supraspinatus tendon.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Fair to say that site doesn't bleed very much?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: It doesn't.  It doesn't have a great blood supply, so you're not going to see a lot of bleeding from there.  If the muscle -- at the junction of the tendon, muscle becomes tendon, tendon inserts some bone.  When that occurs, you may see some bleeding.  But after a month, the body has an amazing ability to shut that down. Any bleeding that occurs in the muscle itself will stop just from coagulation standpoint.  I don't know that he has any medical conditions that would preclude him from being able to coagulate.  It's not an area where you're going to see bleeding into the joint.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That doesn't surprise you that there was no -- you didn't see any bleeding?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: No, especially after a month when the study was done.  I wouldn't expect it to be as intense as if the study was done on the same day.  You might see some of those things, but after this amount of time it's not unusual with this type of tear.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: One moment. Off the record.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Time is 4:46. Off the record.
speaker: THE VIDEOGRAPHER

text: (Whereupon, a discussion was held off the record.)
4:46.  Back on the video record.
speaker: THE VIDEOGRAPHER

text: Doctor, have any of counsel's questions on cross changed your opinion in this matter?
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: Respectfully, I would hold the same opinions.  I wouldn't change any of the ones I gave today.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you for your time.
speaker: MS. MCCARTHY

text: That concludes this deposition.  The time is 4:46.  We are off the record.
speaker: THE VIDEOGRAPHER

text: (Whereupon, the deposition concluded at 4:45 p.m.)

- - - C E R T I F I C A T E I hereby certify that the proceedings, evidence and objections noted are contained fully and accurately in the notes taken by me on this hearing of the above-captioned case on August 29, 2019, and that this is a correct transcription of same.
